awd_titl_txt: Reactive Gas Chemistry in the Dome C Snowpack and its Influence on Surface Layer Chemistry and Ice Core Records
awd_abstract_narration:
This US-French collaboration seeks to further our understanding  of the photochemical processes taking place in snow and firn, and the influences they may have on surface exchange between snowpack and the polar atmosphere. Such processes potentially impact the atmospheric composition of trace gases over the Antarctic continent.  

Vertically and temporally resolved records of ozone, nitrogen oxides (NOx), CO  as well as selected hydrocarbons  in the lower 10m of the atmosphere at Dome C will be sought over the course of this ~1+ season. Shading perturbation  experiments will also be undertaken to investigate photochemical transformations of photochemical oxidants in interstitial snowpack air.  Similar measurements that have been made at Summit (Greenland) will provide a basis for comparison, and a further refinement of a physical and chemical snowpack model depicting our understanding of snowpack-atmosphere chemical cycling in polar ice sheets.  By providing the core of a CU graduate student research project, this effort fosters  international research connections.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: This collaborative US-French research project entailed a ~14-month field experiment at the French/Italian Dome C research station in Antarctica.  In November 2012, an underground laborotory, a meteorological tower, and below surface snow air inlets connected to a sampling system was installed for continuous measurements of reactive gases in the snowpack and in air above the snowpack surface.  Measured species included ozone, nitrogen oxides, gaseous elemental mercury, and formaldehyde.  These gases are formed by photochemical processes triggered by sun light, so they show very strong seasonal cycles due to the stark 24-hour sunlight to 24-hour darkness annual cycle at this 75 degree south, 3233 meters above sea level Antarctic research site. The experiment yielded >97% data coverage representing the first full seasonal cycle of these gases in the interior of Antarctica.  All gases show seasonal concentration changes and very dynamic snow-atmosphere exchanges.  Concentration differences between the snowpack air and ambient air above the surface were applied to infer the fluxes of gases (always from higher to lower concentration gradients).  Determination of these gas exchanges is of importance for deciphering the role of snowpack chemistry on the chemical composition of the atmosphere and the atmospheric reactive gas chemistry.  Occasional events of local exhaust transport from the station power generating plant that uses liquid hydrocarbon fuel exerted a major influence on trace gas levels and chemistry in the snowpack, lasting from a few days to 1-2 weeks.  These observations add important new information to the discussion of if and how snow-photochemical experiments within reach of the power grid of polar research sites are possibly compromised by the snowpack being chemically influenced (contaminated) by gaseous and particulate emissions from the research camp activities. This question is critical for evaluating if snowpack trace chemical measurements from within the camp boundaries are representative for the vast polar ice sheets.  

Broader Impacts:  One female Ph.D. student and one postdoctoral scientist participated in fieldwork at Dome C, and one postdoctoral scientist was supported for data analyses;

Eight conference presentations were given.

Three research papers have been published in peer-reviewed science journals:

Preunkert, S., Legrand, M., Frey, M. M., Kukui, A., Savarino, J., Gallée, H., King, M., Jourdain, B., Vicars, W., and Helmig, D. (2015) Formaldehyde (HCHO) in air, snow, and interstitial air at Concordia (East Antarctic Plateau) in summer, Atmos. Chem. Phys., 15, 6689-6705, doi:10.5194/acp-15-6689-2015.

Legrand M., Preunkert S., Savarino J., Frey M.M., Kukui A., Helmig D., Jourdain B., Jones A.E., Weller R., Brough N., and Gallée H. (2016) Inter-annual variability of surface ozone at coastal (Dumont d'Urville, 2004–2014) and inland (Concordia, 2007–2014) sites in East Antarctica, Atmos. Chem. Phys., 16, 8053-8069.

Angot H., Magand O., Helmig D., Ricaud P., Quennehen B., Gallée H., Del Guasta M., Sprovieri F., Pirrone N., Savarino J., and Dommergue A. (2016) New insights into the atmospheric mercury cycling in central Antarctica and implications on a continental scale, Atmos. Chem. Phys. 16, 8249-8264.

Two more publications are in preparation:

Helmig D., Liptzin D., and Savarino J. (2017) Intrusion, retention, and snowpack chemical effects from fuel combustion exhaust at Dome C, Antarctica.   The Cryosphere.  Manuscript in preparation.

Helmig D., Liptzin D., and Savarino J. (2017) Atmospheric, snowpack, and surface-atmospheric exchange of photo-reactive gases at Dome C, Antarctica.  Journal TBD.   Manuscript in preparation.

This project has resulted in a follow-up research initiative, the ‘East Antarctica International Ice Sheet Traverse’, which is a collaborative French/Italian/Australian/U.S. proposed project for study of glaciology, meteorology, snow physical and chemical transitions from Dome C to South Pole.  Besides many other research objectives, this project would allow accessing and sampling of pristine snow, and conducting similar snow-photochemical studies far away from the influence of Antarctic research camps for further comparison and evaluation of the findings from our experiment at Dome C.
